propositions.text: The narrator is standing with a very handsome man named Claude.
The narrator compares Claude to Brad Pitt, Charles Bronson, and Edward James Olmos.
Claude's ideal type is strong, rough, dark, and potentially stubbled, not curvy and blonde.
Alfred Cumberland, the photographer, instructs Maria-Star Cooper to fix the narrator's hair.
Maria-Star Cooper is a young assistant who previously worked with the narrator during a shifter leader election.
The narrator describes her outfit and the studio environment.
Life has been oppressive for the narrator in the past few weeks.
Maria-Star Cooper, who had been injured by a car, is now fully recovered thanks to werewolf healing abilities.
Maria-Star recognizes the narrator, and the narrator feels relieved.
The narrator was not entirely willing to participate in the shifter leader election.
Alcide Herveaux, son of a failed competitor, feels let down by the narrator.
The new pack leader, Patrick Furnan, is aware of the narrator's connection to the Herveaux family.
Maria-Star applies a lot of makeup to the narrator, making her look great but not like Sookie Stackhouse.
Claude is gay, and if he were not, he would impress the narrator.
Claude is described as tall, with long black hair, brown eyes, and perfect features.
Claude has had ear surgery to make them look human, indicating he is an elf.
Alfred uses a wind machine to create a dramatic effect for the photoshoot.
Claude asks for juice, showing his inexperience.
Maria-Star sighs after learning about Claude, indicating women often regret his sexual orientation.
Maria-Star seems to have something to say to the narrator but hesitates.
The narrator finds telepathy painful and makes dating difficult.
Maria-Star mentions Alcide has been having a hard time since his father was defeated.
The narrator sent a letter to the ASPCA, knowing they would inform Alcide and Janice about their father's death.
The narrator acknowledges she received only a thank you letter from the funeral home.
The narrator experiences pain but has learned to push it away.
The narrator looks through Alfred's sample albums, finding them uncomfortable.
The narrator tells Maria-Star that she and Alcide are not a couple.
Maria-Star expresses awe and possibly fear, saying she heard the narrator can do things.
The narrator reassures Maria-Star she is happy she is dating Alcide.
The narrator realizes Alcide no longer has feelings for her after he didn't mention his father's death.
The narrator admits she liked Alcide and it hurts to be replaced by someone else.
Alcide had previously suggested they live together but is now with a younger werewolf and planning a puppy.
The narrator feels ashamed for her thoughts about Alcide and Maria-Star.
The narrator wishes Maria-Star happiness.
The narrator views a special album containing pictures of supernatural beings, including a vampire couple and a young werewolf transforming.
Alfred gave Claude a chance to be on the cover of a magazine.
Alfred instructs the narrator and Claude to pose intimately for the next set of photos.
The narrator is instructed to lift her skirt to show her legs, which are smooth and tanned.
Claude is instructed to look as if he is about to remove his pants.
Claude's photos are often chosen for the cover of Romantic Times Book Reviews.
Alfred suggested to Claude that women would be interested in romance novel covers and that Claude's eyes would pair well with a blonde.
The narrator agrees to help Claude for free, unlike paid strippers.
Claude removes his shirt, revealing a muscular physique, which the narrator is no longer impressed by.
The narrator feels the act of lifting her skirt is too intimate, even though she is not blushing.
Alfred is displeased with the narrator's expression, wanting her to look like she desires Claude.
The narrator tries to convey desire by lifting her leg and looking at Claude.
Alfred instructs Maria-Star to make the narrator look more eager and to pull down her top.
The narrator is not interested in Claude, finding him temperamental and unresponsive.
The narrator resorts to fantasy.
The narrator's thoughts turn to Vampire Bill, her first love, who is now dating someone else.
The narrator considers Eric, Bill's boss, but dismisses the idea as dangerous.
The narrator also considers her boss, Sam Merlotte, and Alcide Herveaux, but dismisses them.
The narrator recalls a disturbing but titillating past sexual experience involving her bleeding leg being licked by Quinn.
Alfred declares the shot is perfect as Claude's hand touches the narrator's trembling leg.
Alfred suggests a bed scene, but both the narrator and Claude refuse.
The narrator suggests shooting Claude standing in water instead, which Alfred agrees to.
The narrator leaves the dressing room and heads back to work.
Claude thanks the narrator.
The narrator wishes Claude luck with his modeling contract.
Maria-Star says goodbye to the narrator.
The narrator lies about being happy to see Maria-Star.
The narrator questions why Maria-Star doesn't understand her feelings for Alcide, considering his attractive qualities and current success.

concepts.name: Claude
concepts.context: The handsome man the narrator is with for a photoshoot, described as an elf, gay, and aspiring model.

concepts.name: Narrator
concepts.context: The first-person perspective of the story, involved in a photoshoot and reflecting on relationships and supernatural elements.

concepts.name: Alfred Cumberland
concepts.context: The photographer who directs the photoshoot and is knowledgeable about the supernatural world.

concepts.name: Maria-Star Cooper
concepts.context: The assistant to the photographer, a werewolf who seems to have unexpressed feelings for Alcide.

concepts.name: Alcide Herveaux
concepts.context: A werewolf whose father was recently killed; the narrator has unrequited feelings for him, and he is now with Maria-Star.

concepts.name: Supernatural beings
concepts.context: Elves, werewolves, vampires, and shifters, who inhabit the world of the story.

concepts.name: Photoshoot
concepts.context: The main event where the narrator and Claude are participating, involving posing and various instructions from the photographer.

concepts.name: Relationships
concepts.context: The narrator's reflections on her romantic interests, past and present, including Claude, Bill, Eric, Sam, and Alcide.

concepts.name: Shifter leader election
concepts.context: A past event where the narrator was involved and which led to conflict and violence.

concepts.name: Fantasy
concepts.context: The narrator's use of imagination to cope with the uninspiring photoshoot and her romantic disappointments.

hierarchy.structure: The document begins with the narrator in a photoshoot, introduces various characters and their relationships, delves into the narrator's personal reflections and fantasies, and concludes with the resolution of the photoshoot scene.
